top_categories.workout_context: At mile 60 of 85, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
Lost River Classic's Appalachian gravel roads, George Washington National Forest forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 85 miles.
100ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Lost River Classic's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before August.
At Lost River Classic, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Lost River Classic. Train it until it feels boring.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 85 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
8,500ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Lost River Classic, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
The aerobic base that lets you ride technical Appalachian gravel with constant at tempo for 85 miles without cracking. No shortcuts.
8,500ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
Low-cadence force work for 8,500ft of climbing. The slow, grinding ascents where you can't spin—you push.

race_overlay.heat: August in Mathias, West Virginia — Mid-August brings 65-85°F temperatures with 70-90% humidity. Heat index can reach 90-95°F. Afternoon thunderstorm risk moderate. Dense forest canopy provides intermittent shade but traps humidity. Heat management is the defining climate challenge. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Lost River Classic — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day. Race-day realities: High humidity compounds heat stress during long climbs.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Lost River Classic’s 85 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Lost River Classic demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride technical appalachian gravel with constant elevation change at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: appalachian gravel roads, george washington national forest service roads, rocky descents with embedded rocks. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 85 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, Gravel Specific, and TT Threshold to prepare you for 85 miles of technical appalachian gravel with constant elevation change in Mathias, West Virginia.
